captions.text:
-Hi, I'm Mindy from
CuteGirlHairstyles,

and today we're going
to demo the crown braid

or what some people
call the milkmaid braid.

So what you're
going to do is start

by just brushing-- turn
this way a little bit--

all of the hair
away from the face

so that there's no obvious part
lines falling into the hair.

Now, you can do it
on dry or wet hair.

I'm gong to just spritz
it just ever so slightly

through the top,
just so it controls

her fly-aways a
little bit for me.
OK.

When you get that
done, I'm going

to start by braiding
under her left ear.

This is probably the most
unsightly part of the braid

and I want it
hidden so I'm going

to stick it right behind her
ear where it's less noticeable.

So I'm going to gather
up a chunk of hair

and separate it
into three sections

and go ahead and start
my outie French braid

or as some people call it,
the Dutch french braid.

OK, now when I'm
picking up hair,

you can see where
my hair line is

landing, where I've
pulled up hair.

I'm going to pull new hair
sections as close to that
as humanly possible.

And you'll see in a second
why that's so important.

And then of course
in the front, you're

just going to try to keep the
braid as close to her forehead
as possible.

So we continue to braid,
picking up hair pieces.
So we go along.

And I'm just going
to try to keep that
right next to her forehead.
OK.

Now, what I see people
doing a lot on this braid

is they'll pull their
hair back into like,

a ponytail and then pull the
hair strands from the ponytail.

Which works just fine, but
what you end up with at the end

is kind of a bubble in
the back of their head

where you can see the ponytail
sticking out, the elastic.
And I don't love that.

So by keeping the hair strands
right next to the braid, what's

going to happen is
all of this hair

is going to pull down back
over the back of her hair.

And it's going to
look really pretty.

And I'll show you
again in just a minute
what I'm talking about.

One of the hardest
things about this braid

is just keeping it so you
don't have really obvious part
lines anywhere in the hair.

So by braiding it
the way we are,
it prevents that from happening.

OK, so turn your head
this way a little bit.

Now what you can see
is that from the back,
we have very smooth, nice hair.

And when we braid that down at
the back of her neck like this,

we're not going to have any
obvious part lines or ponytail

elastics stick sticking
out in the back.

And we prevented
that from happening

by just braiding really
close to her head.
The front part line.
Sorry.

Hope that made
sense to everybody.

Now as we're going
along and we're

continuing to pull hair
sections in, again, just

keeping the braid
as close to her ears

and now at the nape of
her neck as possible.
Sorry.

And what you can
see happening is

that we get very nice,
natural, hair fallage,
if that's even a word.
OK, turn this way.

Continue to just braid
all the way around.
Turn your body for me.
Thank you.

So we're not cranking
your neck here.

And this hairdo you
can do on yourself.

You have to be a pretty good
braider but it is possible.
Lots of people do it.

OK, and pick up
that last strand.
OK now, right here.

Here's another trick
spot on this hairdo.

What happens, if this is loose
and you pull the braid up

against the head, you're
going to have hair popping out
right there.

So you just want to make sure
that on that last section,

when you pull the hair in,
you pull like, kind of extra
tight against the head.

So that when you
tighten the braid up

and you pull it up against the
head, it's going to lay flat.

And if, for some
reason, you still

get a little hair popping
out, have no fear.

The magic of bobby
pins is amazing.
So it will just fix it.

Have the rubber
band ready, babe.
Thank you.
OK.

So I'm going to use a clear
elastic at the bottom.

It's little and
then it will also
blend into the hair better.
OK.

So can you see how right here
mine is just a smidge loose?

So I'm just getting
a tiny bubble?
That's OK.
We'll fix that with a bobby pin.

You're going to the
hair and wrap it.

And then what I try to
do is tuck the elastic

under one of those
little braid bumps.

And then just take a bobby
pin and kind of bobby

pin that over the
top of that elastic.

Then take the ends
and do the same thing.

Tip you head back just a smidge
so Daddy can get a better shot.
OK.
Tuck, tuck, tuck.

Hold that little
braid over and then

just run a bobby
pin right in there

so that you've got
that nice and hidden.

Now I'm also going to
just take one bobby pin

and just tuck that one
down a little bit more.
OK.

Now I like to go back and tug
on the edges of the braid,
especially up here in front.

It's just going to loosen
the braid a little bit.

It's going to give it a
little extra dynamic look.

It will make your
hair look fuller

than it actually is
if you have thin hair.

And it just kind of pops out
the braid a little bit more.

So anywhere you just want a
little pop, just give it a tug.
And there you go.

You have a beautiful crown
braid with smooth in the back.

And what this turns into the
next day is beautiful waves.

So you can just take
it and brush it out
and have lovely second-do waves.
There you go.
-Bye.

title: The Crown {Carousel} Braid | Updos | Cute Girls Hairstyles
